title: Job Chapter 35 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 35 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 35 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 35.

questions.question: Who is speaking in Job Chapter 35?
questions.correctAnswer: Elihu
questions.explanation: Job 35:1 states, 'Elihu spake moreover, and said,' indicating Elihu is the speaker.

questions.question: In Job 35:2, what does Elihu question about Job's claim?
options: If Job's righteousness is greater than God's
questions.correctAnswer: If Job's righteousness is greater than God's
questions.explanation: Job 35:2 says, 'Thinkest thou this to be right, that thou saidst, My righteousness is more than God's?'

questions.question: According to Job 35:5, what does Elihu tell Job to look at?
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens and the clouds
questions.explanation: Job 35:5 states, 'Look unto the heavens, and see; and behold the clouds which are higher than thou.'

questions.question: What question does Elihu ask in Job 35:6 regarding sin?
questions.correctAnswer: What doest thou against God?
questions.explanation: Job 35:6 asks, 'If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him?'

questions.question: According to Job 35:7, what does Elihu say about righteousness?
questions.correctAnswer: What givest thou him?
questions.explanation: Job 35:7 says, 'If thou be righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand?'

questions.question: What does Elihu say about wickedness and righteousness in Job 35:8?
options: Wickedness may hurt a man, and righteousness may profit the son of man
Wickedness brings blessings, righteousness brings sorrow
Both wickedness and righteousness have no effect
Wickedness profits men, righteousness hurts them
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness may hurt a man, and righteousness may profit the son of man
questions.explanation: Job 35:8 states, 'Thy wickedness may hurt a man as thou art; and thy righteousness may profit the son of man.'

questions.question: In Job 35:9, why do the oppressed cry out?
options: Because of the arm of the mighty
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the arm of the mighty
questions.explanation: Job 35:9 says, 'By reason of the multitude of oppressions they make the oppressed to cry: they cry out by reason of the arm of the mighty.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 35:10 states that people ask, 'Where is God my maker?'
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 35:10 says, 'But none saith, Where is God my maker,' meaning no one asks this.

questions.question: According to Job 35:11, who teaches us more and makes us wiser than them?
options: The beasts of the earth and the fowls of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Job 35:11 says, 'Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven?' referring to God.

questions.question: What reason does Job 35:12 give for no answers when people cry out?
options: Because of the pride of evil men
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the pride of evil men
questions.explanation: Job 35:12 states, 'There they cry, but none giveth answer, because of the pride of evil men.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 35:13 says God will hear vanity and regard it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 35:13 says, 'Surely God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty regard it.'

questions.question: What does Job 35:14 encourage to do despite not seeing God?
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in Him
questions.explanation: Job 35:14 says, '...therefore trust thou in him.'

questions.question: According to Job 35:15, how has God visited because it is not so?
questions.correctAnswer: In his anger
questions.explanation: Job 35:15 states, 'But now, because it is not so, he hath visited in his anger.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 35:16 says Job speaks with knowledge and wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 35:16 says, 'Therefore doth Job open his mouth in vain; he multiplieth words without knowledge.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 35:10: 'But none saith, Where is God my _______'?
questions.correctAnswer: maker
questions.explanation: Job 35:10 says, 'But none saith, Where is God my maker,' making 'maker' the correct word.

medium.title: Job Chapter 35 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 35 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer questions the value of righteousness before God, asking what profit comes from being cleansed from sin. Based on Job 35, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to human righteousness and wickedness?
options: God receives nothing from human righteousness or wickedness
God rewards human righteousness with earthly riches
God punishes wickedness but ignores righteousness
Human righteousness earns God’s favor and blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God receives nothing from human righteousness or wickedness
questions.explanation: Job 35:6-7 teaches that if one sins or is righteous, it does not affect God directly—He receives nothing from our deeds. This highlights God's transcendence and calls believers to trust Him rather than rely on personal merit.

questions.question: How does Job 35 instruct us to respond when facing unjust oppression and suffering in life?
options: Cry out to God because He hears the oppressed
Ignore God because He does not listen
Rely on human strength to overcome
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to God because He hears the oppressed
questions.explanation: Job 35:9-10 acknowledges that the oppressed cry out due to the arm of the mighty, and God is the maker who gives songs in the night, symbolizing hope and comfort for those who trust Him.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with doubt about whether God listens to their prayers. According to Job 35, what reason is given for God sometimes not responding?
options: Because of the pride of evil men
Because God is unaware of their cries
Because God is busy with other matters
Because prayers must be loud enough
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the pride of evil men
questions.explanation: Job 35:12-13 explains that God does not answer cries when they are vain or motivated by pride and evil, emphasizing humility and sincere repentance in prayer.

questions.question: In Job 35, what does Elihu say about human sin and its effect on God?
options: Human sin does not harm God
Sin causes God to punish immediately
God is weakened by human sin
Sin blinds God to human needs
questions.correctAnswer: Human sin does not harm God
questions.explanation: Job 35:6 states that if a person sins, it does not affect God directly, highlighting God's sovereignty and holiness apart from human actions.

questions.question: How does Job 35 encourage believers to view God’s judgment and trust during trials?
options: Judgment is before God, so trust Him
God ignores judgment in times of suffering
Trust only after seeing clear evidence
Judgment is uncertain, so rely on self
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment is before God, so trust Him
questions.explanation: Job 35:14 teaches that although one may feel they do not see God, judgment is before Him, encouraging trust in God’s righteous governance even in difficult times.

questions.question: What does Job 35 reveal about God’s knowledge of human suffering and anger?
options: God visits in anger but knows suffering is not extreme
questions.correctAnswer: God visits in anger but knows suffering is not extreme
questions.explanation: Job 35:15 explains that although God may visit in anger, He understands when suffering is not severe, showing His measured justice and mercy.

questions.question: According to Job 35, what is the effect of a person's righteousness on others?
options: It may profit the son of man
questions.correctAnswer: It may profit the son of man
questions.explanation: Job 35:8 states that while wickedness may hurt a man, righteousness may benefit others, encouraging believers to live righteously for the good of their community.

questions.question: True or False: Job 35 teaches that God will hear and answer all cries regardless of their nature.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 35:12-13 clarifies that God will not hear vanity or prideful cries, emphasizing the importance of humility and sincere prayer.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 35, God teaches humans wisdom beyond that of animals.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 35:11 states that God teaches humans more than the beasts and makes them wiser than the birds, highlighting God’s role in human understanding.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elihu encourages Job to "Look unto the _____, and see; and behold the clouds which are higher than thou."
questions.correctAnswer: heavens
questions.explanation: Job 35:5 instructs to look to the heavens and see the clouds above, symbolizing God's greatness beyond human reach.

questions.question: How does Job 35 illustrate the importance of humility in prayer and speech?
options: Prideful words are counted as vanity and ignored by God
One must argue with God to be heard
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful words are counted as vanity and ignored by God
questions.explanation: Job 35:12-13 and 35:16 show that pride and speaking without knowledge lead to prayers and words that God does not regard, underscoring humility and wisdom.

questions.question: A believer wonders if their righteousness earns God’s favor. Based on Job 35, what practical insight would you share?
options: Righteousness does not give God anything; trust Him anyway
God rewards only those who boast of their righteousness
Righteousness is a bargaining tool with God
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness does not give God anything; trust Him anyway
questions.explanation: Job 35:7 teaches that righteousness does not give God anything directly, inviting believers to trust God’s grace rather than rely on their own merit.

questions.question: What biblical principle about God’s justice can be drawn from Job 35:14 when facing unanswered prayers or unseen judgment?
options: Judgment is always before God; therefore, trust Him
God does not judge the wicked
Only immediate justice is true justice
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment is always before God; therefore, trust Him
questions.explanation: Job 35:14 encourages believers to trust God’s judgment even if it seems unseen, affirming faith in His sovereign justice.

questions.question: How does Job 35 teach about the relationship between human words and knowledge?
options: Speaking without knowledge leads to vain words
questions.correctAnswer: Speaking without knowledge leads to vain words
questions.explanation: Job 35:16 highlights that Job multiplies words without knowledge, indicating that speech should be grounded in understanding and humility.

questions.question: What does Elihu challenge Job about his attitude toward God's righteousness in Job 35:2?
options: Job claims his righteousness is greater than God's
Job praises God's righteousness above all
Job ignores the concept of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Job claims his righteousness is greater than God's
questions.explanation: Job 35:2 questions Job’s statement implying his righteousness surpasses God's, challenging pride and misunderstanding of God's holiness.

hard.title: Job Chapter 35 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 35.

questions.question: In Job 35:2, Elihu challenges Job's claim about his righteousness. What does Elihu say Job thinks about his righteousness compared to God's?
options: My righteousness is more than God's
My righteousness is equal to God's
My righteousness is less than God's
My righteousness is unknown to God
questions.correctAnswer: My righteousness is more than God's
questions.explanation: Elihu explicitly states in Job 35:2 that Job said, 'My righteousness is more than God's,' challenging Job's claim.

questions.question: According to Job 35:5, what is Elihu's suggested method for Job to understand his situation?
options: Look unto the heavens and see the clouds which are higher than thou
Study the laws of Moses carefully
Seek the wisdom of the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Look unto the heavens and see the clouds which are higher than thou
questions.explanation: Elihu directs Job to look at the heavens and consider the clouds above him to gain perspective, as seen in Job 35:5.

questions.question: In Job 35:6, Elihu asks what effect sin has on God. What is the implied answer regarding human sinfulness and God?
options: No effect; human sin does not harm God
God is angered greatly by sin
Sin demands immediate punishment from God
Sin causes God to withdraw His blessings
questions.correctAnswer: No effect; human sin does not harm God
questions.explanation: Verse 6 asks, 'If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him?' implying that human sin does not impact God directly.

questions.question: Job 35:7 raises a question about what the righteous can give to God. What is Elihu's point in asking this?
options: Righteousness does not bring anything to God
Righteousness earns great rewards from God
God demands offerings from the righteous
The righteous bring glory to God
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness does not bring anything to God
questions.explanation: Elihu queries in verse 7, 'If thou be righteous, what givest thou him?' to emphasize that righteousness does not benefit God materially.

questions.question: How does Job 35:8 describe the effect of wickedness and righteousness on humans?
options: Wickedness may hurt a man, and righteousness may profit the son of man
Wickedness benefits the wicked, and righteousness harms the righteous
Both wickedness and righteousness are irrelevant to man
Wickedness and righteousness are equally rewarded by God
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness may hurt a man, and righteousness may profit the son of man
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states that wickedness may harm a man like Job, while righteousness can benefit humanity.

questions.question: According to Job 35:9-10, what do the oppressed do, and what is notably absent in their cries?
options: They cry out due to oppression, but none asks for God the maker
They sing songs of praise to God in the night
They offer sacrifices to appease God
They seek wisdom from beasts and birds
questions.correctAnswer: They cry out due to oppression, but none asks for God the maker
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 describe that oppressed people cry out because of the mighty, but none asks, 'Where is God my maker?' who gives songs in the night.

questions.question: What unique teaching role does God have according to Job 35:11?
options: He teaches us more than the beasts of the earth and makes us wiser than the fowls of heaven
He teaches only priests and prophets
He teaches through the law given to Moses
questions.correctAnswer: He teaches us more than the beasts of the earth and makes us wiser than the fowls of heaven
questions.explanation: Job 35:11 states God teaches humans more than animals and grants them greater wisdom.

questions.question: In Job 35:12, why do cries go unanswered according to Elihu?
options: Because of the pride of evil men
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the pride of evil men
questions.explanation: Verse 12 explains that cries go unanswered due to the pride of the wicked, highlighting human culpability.

questions.question: What does Job 35:13 say about God's response to vanity and the Almighty's regard for it?
options: God will not hear vanity, nor will the Almighty regard it
God is indifferent to all human speech
questions.correctAnswer: God will not hear vanity, nor will the Almighty regard it
questions.explanation: Elihu declares in verse 13 that God does not listen to meaningless or vain talk.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 35:14 says, 'Although thou sayest thou shalt not see him, yet ______ is before him; therefore trust thou in him.'
questions.correctAnswer: judgment
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes 'judgment' being before God, urging trust despite feelings of divine hiddenness.

questions.question: How does Job 35:15 describe God's current attitude towards Job's suffering?
options: God has visited in anger but does not know it in great extremity
God is fully aware and angry at Job
God is pleased with Job's faith
questions.correctAnswer: God has visited in anger but does not know it in great extremity
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes God’s visitation in anger but suggests it is not with great severity or full awareness.

questions.question: What is Elihu's assessment of Job's speech in Job 35:16?
options: Job opens his mouth in vain and multiplies words without knowledge
Job speaks with wisdom and understanding
Job's words are comforting to his friends
questions.correctAnswer: Job opens his mouth in vain and multiplies words without knowledge
questions.explanation: Elihu criticizes Job in verse 16 for speaking without true understanding, indicating his words are futile.

questions.question: True or False: Job 35:10 mentions that God gives songs in the night.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 says, 'God my maker, who giveth songs in the night,' affirming this statement.

questions.question: How does the theme of divine justice in Job 35:14 relate to the broader biblical context, such as in Psalms or Isaiah?
options: Judgment before God is a consistent theme, urging trust despite unseen justice
Divine justice is only revealed in the New Testament
God's judgment is arbitrary and unpredictable
Judgment is a minor theme in Scripture
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment before God is a consistent theme, urging trust despite unseen justice
questions.explanation: Job 35:14's mention of 'judgment before him' parallels themes in Psalms (e.g., Psalm 33:5) and Isaiah where trust in God's justice is emphasized.

questions.question: Considering the ancient Near Eastern context, why might Elihu emphasize that human actions do not affect God directly as in Job 35:6-7?
options: To contrast human limitations with divine transcendence common in ANE theology
Because gods in ANE were believed to be controlled by humans
To deny God's involvement in human affairs
To promote human independence from any deity
questions.correctAnswer: To contrast human limitations with divine transcendence common in ANE theology
questions.explanation: Elihu's emphasis reflects the ANE understanding of divine transcendence—God is above human actions and unaffected directly by sin or righteousness.

theological.title: Job Chapter 35 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 35 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Elihu in Job 35, what is the implication of Job claiming his righteousness is greater than God's?
options: It questions the justice of God
It is considered a right statement
It reflects a misunderstanding of divine righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a misunderstanding of divine righteousness
questions.explanation: Job 35:2 challenges Job's claim, indicating that saying 'My righteousness is more than God's' is not right. The divine righteousness is supreme and incomparable, consistent with Romans 3:4 and Isaiah 45:21 where God's righteousness is absolute.

questions.question: What does Elihu suggest about the effect of sin on God in Job 35?
options: Sin causes God to punish immediately
Sin does not affect God directly
questions.correctAnswer: Sin does not affect God directly
questions.explanation: Job 35:6 asks rhetorically 'If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him?' highlighting that human sin does not bring direct harm to God. This aligns with Habakkuk 1:13 and Psalm 50:21 which indicate God's holiness and transcendence above sin.

questions.question: In Job 35, what is said about the profit or gift a righteous person gives to God?
options: God receives gifts from the righteous
God receives nothing from man's righteousness
Righteousness is a debt to God
questions.correctAnswer: God receives nothing from man's righteousness
questions.explanation: Job 35:7 states 'If thou be righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand?' indicating that God's nature is not dependent on human righteousness. This is consistent with Isaiah 64:6 and Psalm 49:7 which emphasize that human righteousness cannot earn God’s favor.

questions.question: What reason does Elihu give in Job 35 for why people cry out in oppression?
options: Because of the arm of the mighty
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the arm of the mighty
questions.explanation: Job 35:9 says oppressed people cry out due to 'the arm of the mighty,' indicating that human oppression causes suffering. This parallels Exodus 3:7 and Psalm 9:9 which speak of God hearing the oppressed and acting against the mighty.

questions.question: What does Job 35 say about who gives songs in the night?
options: God, the maker, gives songs in the night
The beasts of the earth give songs
questions.correctAnswer: God, the maker, gives songs in the night
questions.explanation: Job 35:10 refers to God as 'my maker, who giveth songs in the night,' indicating God's sustaining and comforting presence. This aligns with Psalm 42:8 and Zephaniah 3:17 which depict God providing comfort and joy in times of darkness.

questions.question: According to Job 35, who teaches humans more than the beasts of the earth and makes them wiser than the birds of heaven?
options: God teaches and makes humans wiser
questions.correctAnswer: God teaches and makes humans wiser
questions.explanation: Job 35:11 states God 'teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven,' emphasizing divine instruction and wisdom. This corresponds to Proverbs 2:6 and Psalm 32:8 where God is the source of wisdom and guidance.

questions.question: What is said in Job 35 about the response to cries for help among the oppressed?
options: No one gives answer because of evil men's pride
questions.correctAnswer: No one gives answer because of evil men's pride
questions.explanation: Job 35:12 explains 'There they cry, but none giveth answer, because of the pride of evil men,' showing that human arrogance can prevent justice. This is consistent with Proverbs 21:13 and Isaiah 59:7 which lament the silence or injustice caused by the wicked.

questions.question: What does Job 35 declare about God hearing vanity and the Almighty regarding it?
options: God does not hear vanity nor regard it
questions.correctAnswer: God does not hear vanity nor regard it
questions.explanation: Job 35:13 says 'Surely God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty regard it,' teaching God's holiness and intolerance for empty or foolish speech, consistent with Psalm 34:15 and Ecclesiastes 5:2 which warn against vain words before God.

questions.question: Despite Job's claim that he will not see God, what does Elihu say about judgment in Job 35?
options: Judgment is before God, so trust Him
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment is before God, so trust Him
questions.explanation: Job 35:14 says 'yet judgment is before him; therefore trust thou in him,' affirming God's sovereign oversight of judgment, aligning with Hebrews 10:30 and Romans 14:11 which affirm God's authority to judge and the call to trust Him.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about God's anger and knowledge of human suffering in Job 35?
options: God's anger is always fully aware of extremity
God has visited in anger but does not know it in great extremity
God fully knows every detail of suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God has visited in anger but does not know it in great extremity
questions.explanation: Job 35:15 states that God has visited in anger but 'he knoweth it not in great extremity,' implying God's disciplined judgment is measured. This relates to Nahum 1:3 and Lamentations 3:33 showing God's anger is just but controlled.

questions.question: What is said about Job's speech in Job 35?
options: Job speaks wisely and with understanding
Job opens his mouth in vain and multiplies words without knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Job opens his mouth in vain and multiplies words without knowledge
questions.explanation: Job 35:16 critiques Job's speech as 'in vain,' reflecting lack of true understanding. This is consistent with Proverbs 18:13 and Ecclesiastes 5:2 which caution against speaking without knowledge.

questions.question: In Job 35, what does Elihu say about the advantage or profit Job questioned regarding cleansing from sin?
options: Cleansing from sin has no advantage
There is great profit in being cleansed from sin
questions.correctAnswer: There is great profit in being cleansed from sin
questions.explanation: Job 35:3 references Job's question about the profit of being cleansed, which Elihu responds to by implying there is indeed profit. This aligns with Isaiah 1:18 and 1 John 1:9 emphasizing forgiveness and cleansing bring spiritual benefit.

questions.question: What does Elihu advise Job and his companions to do in Job 35?
options: Look unto the heavens and behold the clouds
questions.correctAnswer: Look unto the heavens and behold the clouds
questions.explanation: Job 35:5 exhorts Job to observe the heavens and clouds above, signifying God's transcendence and sovereignty. This reflects Psalm 19:1 and Isaiah 40:26 showing God's majesty in creation.

questions.question: According to Job 35, how does human wickedness and righteousness affect others?
options: Wickedness and righteousness only affect God
Wickedness may hurt man, righteousness may profit man
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness may hurt man, righteousness may profit man
questions.explanation: Job 35:8 states 'Thy wickedness may hurt a man as thou art; and thy righteousness may profit the son of man,' indicating human actions affect others, consistent with Proverbs 11:17 and Galatians 6:7 which teach about consequences of actions.

questions.question: How does Job 35 depict God's role as Maker in relation to human wisdom?
options: God is irrelevant to human wisdom
God makes humans wiser than birds and teaches them
questions.correctAnswer: God makes humans wiser than birds and teaches them
questions.explanation: Job 35:11 shows God as the Maker who teaches and imparts wisdom, consistent with James 1:5 and Proverbs 2:6 which attribute wisdom to God's gift.
